headline: Plum Crisp
description: This plum crisp is a simple fruit dessert with a sweet baked topping drizzled with butter that uses fresh summer plums for an easy, delicious treat.
name: Plum Crisp

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease an 8x8-inch baking dish.
Spread plums evenly into the prepared baking dish and sprinkle with 1/4 cup sugar.
Mix together flour, remaining 3/4 cup sugar, baking powder, and salt in a large bowl. Stir in beaten egg and spoon mixture over plums. Drizzle batter with melted butter.
Bake in the preheated oven until the topping is brown, about 40 minutes.

review.reviewBody: I had several plums and a couple nectarines left over and thank for this recipe. I am gluten free and so I had to change it a little bit. I used Bob's Red Mill gluten free 1 to 1 baking flour. I added the melted butter to the dry ingredients. I then put the topping over the fruit. I had to cook it 20 min longer and it turned out like a cobbler. I was delightful. I have never used plums in a cobbler but after making this I will now. Thank you.
Delicious. Only change is I used 1/4 C less sugar because my plums were sweetener this year. Thanks!

I added lemon juice, cinnamon, and allspice. Otherwise made as directed and it was delicious!! I honestly wasn’t expecting much but I was so surprised. It is a little tart, but I appreciate that in a dessert.

It sounded a bit bland, so I made a few alterations: I replaced three of the plums with nectarines. Instead of white sugar, I sprinkled coconut sugar over the fruit. I used white sugar in the flour mixture and added 1/8 tsp cardamom and 1/4 tsp cinnamon. It was wonderful! It took a lot longer than 45 min to bake, though. The topping wasn't browned for 1 1/2 hours.

Had an abundance of plums from our tree this year, so I was looking for a way to utilize them and came across this recipe. I made it according to the directions, except I did sprinkle the top with brown sugar before baking, as a few suggested. Overall it was good, but if your plums have tart skin, I would strongly recommend you peel the majority of the fruit. I did not do this and the crisp was very tart, almost bitter, because of it; even ice cream was only a marginal improvement. I think this recipe would also work well with other fruits such as peaches or blackberries. I will try it again with plums too, but I will definitely peel the fruit first. (Photos are before and after baking)

I had to use google to understand the measurements for the butter down here in nz... 1/2 cup of melted butter being 120grams of butter. Also, our standard butter here is salted. So, adding a teaspoon of salt to the recipe also made it too salty. It was also too buttery. It was not nice eating the plums and seeing them in a little pool of butter. I didn't like anything about this, except the plums. Will never make it again.
Very good! I doubled it, added 1/4 tsp of vanilla extract, and sprinkled the fruit with cinnamon. I also substituted brown sugar for white in the topping. Turned out great!

Love this recipe, although I change the flour up too (1/2 c. oats and 1/2 c flour) with a bit of cinnamon and vanilla in the topping. It's a great way to use up extra plums (or just buy the to make the recipe!)
I bought a bunch of yellow plums and didn't want them to go to waste. it turned out great! I made a double batch and added a little cardamom. Definitely saving this recipe.
It didn’t turn out so crispy as expected. It was easy to make and I like the taste.
I feel that unless you follow the recipe AS IS you really can’t rate it. I followed and we loved it! The topping turned out nice and crunchy and the plum filling had a touch of tartness. 3xcellent!
Simple recipe! I doubled it and used canned plums I had on hand.
added oats to replace some flour, added brown sugar to crust versus white, added a wee bit of almond extract and cinnamon

Delicious!!! Now I have something to do with lots of leftover plums. I sprinkled plums with 1t vanilla before adding batter. I reduced white sugar by 1/4C and added 1/4C brown sugar on top. I think I’ll try 1/2C substitution next time as I really like the flavor the brown sugar adds. I also put in 9x13 pan to have more of the crisp topping, my favorite part!
Tasted great! Perfect mix of sour and sweet! I think I will try this recipe with blueberries next.
Our neighbors gave us some plums and we didn't know what to do with them until I found this recipe. My husband and I loved it. Definitely a keeper.
Although I made an error and added the butter to the dough, it was fine!

This is such an easy and delicious recipe. I used Italian prunes since I have 2 trees and 700,000 plums this year. (Only a slight exaggeration). As they’re small I used 6 extra plums to cover the 8x8 baking dish. I also added a 1/4 tsp of cinnamon to the sugar sprinkled on the plums and the same to the crumble topping. Basically, I found this recipe to be perfect. We enjoyed it chilled as it is a rich dessert. Now on to the other 699, 982 plums!
Tastes yummy. I ended up just putting everything in a bowl mixing it till the plum slices were coated and put it back in the 8 x 8 pan.
It worked ever so well and was quick and easy to make. I haven’t got much of a sweet tooth, so I only used a third of the sugar. It was delicious.
Beautiful dessert dish, good with vanilla ice-cream topping!

I used green plums they were a bit on the tart side. Next time I will use cinnamon and sugar. To give more flavor. The sugar alone just sweet didn't taste the plums. I going play with recipe if the creator of this doesn't mind.

Big hit with our family! I added vanilla and cinnamon to the chopped plums as others mentioned. I switched up 1/2 the granulated sugar in the topping for brown sugar. I swapped 1/2 the flour for quick-cooking oats. I also added about 1/4 cup of roughly chopped pecans to the topping for a little texture. This was a great recipe to make use of the plums I had on hand! I will definitely make again when I have peaches or plums around.
Delicious, made it 3 times! added cinnamon and vanilla. Will make it again.

Great recipe. I used half flour and half rolled oats. I used brown sugar with the flour mixture and probably used 3/4 c (I didn't measure). I also didn't melt the butter and I just used soften butter and crumbled/mixed it with the flour with my hands. Cooked in toaster oven at 350 for 30 minutes and it was perfect.
I had extra plums and tried this recipe. Based on other reviewers’ comments, I used half flour and half oatmeal. I did use the egg. I added pumpkin pie spice, too. Big hit!!!!!
Too tangy for us without vanilla ice cream! I would probably increase the sugar more if I made it again.

Yum! Replaced part of the plums with fresh peaches and a few blueberries. Used 2 eggs, added allspice 1/2 tsp. Used sugar as follows: 1/4 cup white sugar on the fruit, 1/2 cup white sugar mixed with flour, 1/4 cup dark brown sugar sprinkled on top. Used 1/2 cup unbleached white and 1/2 cup whole wheat. Will definitely make again ... fun recipe to tweak ... husband loved it!
Very good recipe. Made with red plums, brown sugar, and half oats and half flower.
It was easy and tasty. Will make this again.

I made this in the winter with winter plums. I reduced the sugar and added some pie spice to the plums and a little cinnamon to the topping and it made a delicious christmas plum crisp. This recipe couldn't be easier and it is really buttery, so it was a real win in my house.
I added a little bit of mixed berries just to give it some more filling and a little extra tartness. It turned out very well.

Wonderful! I did as someone suggested and added cinnamon, vanilla extract (mixed in with the sugar into the plums) and brown sugar (& added a little bit of extra sugar so it wouldn't be too tart). Was beautiful and tasted great. I highly recommend serving it with whipped topping on top of each warm piece. My husband LOVED it!

I’ve made this plum crisp several times, as my neighbor has an abundance of plums and shares them with me! I didn’t use as much sugar as the lemon yellow plums are very sweet. The topping is delicious!
Really good, but just had to cook a little bit longer than the 40 min. (50 min)
This is a great recipe! I make it will different types of fruit - peaches, blueberries, blackberries, you name it! I also add vanilla to the fruit mix which gives it an extra yummy flavor!
This plum crisp is super easy to make and delicious but it was a bit too sweet for me. I will reduce the amount of sugar next time I make it.

I followed the recipe without changing anything. The biscuit topping is too salty for my taste and I could have added a little more sugar to the filling. I will make again sometime and make the adjustments.
Great recipe! Easy and the topping turned out really well. I don't think I have made a crisp topping with egg in it. It works!
I will definitely make this again. But not just with plums. The topping will compliment a variety of fresh fruits. Delicious.

made this recipe as is except I added a bit of cinnamon to the crumble. We used sugar plums and it turned out very good. we especially liked the crumble.in this recipe and I will be using it on all my fruit cobblers from now on. Very simple and tasty recipe!
Turned out great. The ladies who lunch enjoyed it!
It was wonderful. I added cinnamon and vanilla to the plums.

Perfect with my very ripe plums. I like it tart.
I have already made this twice in two weeks. So easy and a great flavor.
Excellent recipe! Simple, but delicious... even when I halved the butter

I added a bit less sugar and didn’t need 12 plums to fill the pan. I would make it again, it’s super easy!
Prefer a more traditional crumb topping. Plums (at least my very juicy ones) need to be combined with some thickening agent. Ended up with a plum soup covered with crust.

Turned out good! Delicious. I used 36 small (ping-pong to golf ball sized) plums. As others suggested, I sprinkled cinnamon and vanilla on the fruit. The best addition is I added chopped walnuts to the top as the last step. That made the topping nice and crunchy. I added cinnamon over the top of it and baked it in a 9x13 baking dish. It turned out delicious!
Love the topping. I’ve made this with other fruit and it’s great,
I added a lot more sugar,and it tasted both sweet and sour

I am not a plum person just saying that up front. This plum recipe was so good I had seconds. Hot and right out of the oven with vanilla ice cream really amazing. Definitely making it again when we get some plums.
Blech. Topping was too salty. I think the recipes amount were off.
I made this with fresh blackberries and cut back on some of the sugar. It was amazing! My husband and I raved about it each time we had it.

I made it with plums, blueberries, and a small apple I had that was not getting eaten. I added a splash of vanilla to the wet ingredients and some pumpkin pie spice to the dry. Used half flour, half oats and mixed the butter in with the dry before spreading it on top. Then I sprinkled the top with cinnamon and brown sugar as per others' suggestions. Turned out sweeter than I expected without modifying the sugar. Had it for dessert and breakfast the next morning! yum!

I have made this twice now with the Italian Plums from the tree in my backyard in WA state. After reading other reviews, I let my chopped plums sit in a mix of vanilla an cinnamon before using them in the recipe. It came out delicious both times that I have made it now and this recipe will probably become a tradition for my family every autumn when our plums are ripe and ready to pick.
Tastes horrible. You can taste the egg. Should’ve stuck with my old recipe. Tastes egg-ish. Yuck.
my Mom made Apple Crisp in one of her pyrex bowls a lot. this is s nice variation! i reduced the sugar by a quarter cup. yum

pretty meh The kids didn't like it at all. I prefer an oatmeal based topping. Won't be doing this one again.
Delicious . . .even after accidentally leaving it under the broiler (for a little more brown on top) too long. Husband loved the char !
It was yummy, however next time I will double the amount of plums.
The recipe was good. I would not make any changes.

I doubled the recipe. I used about 16 black plums. They were quite sweet, so I skipped adding sugar to the plums. I added about a teaspoon of allspice to the flour and sugar and two teaspoons of vanilla to the eggs of my double batch. I did not double the butter, instead used only the original 1/2 cup. I added 3/4 tsp. cinnamon, dash of freshly grated nutmeg, dash of salt and 1 teaspoon fresh lemon juice and 1/4 tsp. of almond extract with the 1/4 cup white sugar and mixed this in with 3 large plums, 2 large peaches and 1 large nectarine. I have a crisp recipe I have used forever- 1/2 cup flour, 1/2 cup brown sugar, dash of salt 1/2 tsp baking soda. Mix this well and add 1/4 cup melted butter and sprinkle over top fruit.

I made it exactly like the recipe stated.
I used various plums including Italian and some red flesh and white flesh varieties, basically what I had laying around and starting to get near the end of their tastiness.
It was very easy to make and turned out quite good.

This turned out to be sooooo good! I did have to use 2 eggs for my crisp and I added some cinnamon and vanilla as well before putting the crisp on top. This is such a nice balance of tang and sweetness! I love it!

No I didn’t make any changes it was most delicious
And yes I will make it again, thank you very much
My family loved it!

I only substituted butter for olive oil per the substition measures and of course added cinnamon and allspice in the fruit and cinnamon on the top. It lasted only a day! My family loved it!!
Add brown sugar to the too and yes I will make it again

I followed recipe as instructed with no substitutions. The recipe turned out quite well. I had to increase the baking time an additional 15 minutes in order for the center of the crisp to be thoroughly cooked. I didn't want the cooked plums to be too dark so I peeled them. I used 12 plums since my plums were large. The crisp was good. Pairing it with ice cream or whipped cream is definitely a must to offset the tartness of the crisp.

The extra flour was to help with texture. I was able to roll out the dougj into the shape of the pan.

Very good. When I first made it, I forgot to sprinkle the fourth cup of sugar over the plums before adding the topping. It was still delicious with the contrast between tart and sweet. I copied this recipe to keep. The recipe didn't say whether or not to peel the plums. I did--it was easy to pull the skins off with just my fingers. That may have to do with the variety of plum I used. The plum tree was here when we moved in, so I don't know what kind of is.
Very tangy dessert, I used small plums and did not take the skin off which made it very sour, but with ice cream it’s great!
